facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 330 of 1956 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 330 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and decree dated September 5, 1955, of the Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and decree dated September 5, 1955 of Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and decree dated September 5, 1955, of the Rajasthan High Court in Writ Petition No. 76 of 1954. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Ratnaparkhi A. G., for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State. He was appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed on January 29, 1948, in the grade of Rs. 500-40-700 and worked as such till April 7, 1949. On that date a new State of Rajasthan was formed by the integration of a number of States  including the former State of Bikaner  by means of a Covenant signed by the High Contracting Parties.

facts.text: New State of Rajasthan formed on April 7, 1949 by integration including former Bikaner State via Covenant.

anchor.surface_text: On that date a new State of Rajasthan was formed by the integration of a number of States  including the former State of Bikaner  by means of a Covenant signed by the High Contracting Parties. Article XVI  1  of the Covenant ran thus The United State hereby guarantees either the companytinuance in service of the permanent members of 1015 the public services of the former Rajasthan State and of each of the new Covenanting States on companyditions which will number be less advantageous than those on which they were serving on the 1st November 1948 or the payment of reasonable companysation or retirement on proportionate pension.

facts.text: Article XVI of Covenant guarantees continuance in service on not less advantageous conditions than on November 1, 1948, or compensation or pension.

anchor.surface_text: Article XVI  1  of the Covenant ran thus The United State hereby guarantees either the companytinuance in service of the permanent members of 1015 the public services of the former Rajasthan State and of each of the new Covenanting States on companyditions which will number be less advantageous than those on which they were serving on the 1st November 1948 or the payment of reasonable companysation or retirement on proportionate pension. The integration necessarily involved a reorganisation of the various services in the several integrating States.

facts.text: Twenty eight Courts of District and Sessions Judges reduced to fifteen in integrated State.

anchor.surface_text: On the judicial side it was found that there were as many as twenty eight Courts of District and Sessions Judges in the aggregate. In the integrated State it was proposed to have only fifteen.

facts.text: Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950 set out interim ad hoc postings of judicial officers.

anchor.surface_text: These arrangements are set out in a Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950. We append the relevant extracts In Appendix F have been indicated the provisional postings on an ad hoc basis of the posts specified in Appendices A to E.

facts.text: Appellant appointed ad hoc as Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in Jaipur Division per May 25, 1950 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed under this beading in Part 11 as a Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in the Jaipur Division. But before this Notification was made, namely, on December 9, 1949, the appellant received the following order from the new Rajasthan Government Shri Amar Singh, District and Sessions Judge, Churu, is transferred to Ganganagar as District and Sessions Judge, Ganganagar.

facts.text: On December 9, 1949, appellant transferred from Churu to Ganganagar as District and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: But before this Notification was made, namely, on December 9, 1949, the appellant received the following order from the new Rajasthan Government Shri Amar Singh, District and Sessions Judge, Churu, is transferred to Ganganagar as District and Sessions Judge, Ganganagar. 1016 Among other companytentions, the appellant relies on this as an election by the new Government to companytinue him in his original post and companytends that it companyld number later change its mind and make his service provisional as it purported to do in the numberification just cited.

facts.text: Appellant's increment sanctioned on July 31, 1950 effective from March 23, 1950, raising salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Two months after the numberification, namely on July 31, 1950, the appellants increment became due and Government sanctioned it in the following terms Sanction is accorded to the grant of a stipulated increment of Rs. 40 p.m. in the scale of Rs. 500-40-700 to Shri Rajvi Amarsingh, District and Sessions Judge in Bikaner Division, with effect from the 23rd March, 1950, thereby raising his salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580 p.m.

facts.text: Appellant made representation to Government of Rajasthan on September 11, 1950 against May 25, 1950 posting.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1950, the appellant made a representation to the Government of Rajasthan against his posting of May 25, 1950, as an ad, hoc Civil and Additional Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Ad hoc postings were without prejudice to claims for permanent positions, allegation admitted by opposite party.

anchor.surface_text: He says in his writ petition to the High Court that he was given to understand that these ad hoc postings were without prejudice to the claims of the Government servants for a suitable position in the integrated set up on permanent basis. This allegation was admitted by the opposite party.

facts.text: Appellant appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951, placed in Group C at No. 18.

anchor.surface_text: Later, he was appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951. He was placed in Group C  Civil Judges and Munsiffs  and placed at No. 18 in the list of junior posts. His pay and emoluments were as before and he retained the same grading, namely Rs. 500-40-700.

facts.text: Appellant's pay, emoluments, grading remained same as before, earned increments not affected.

anchor.surface_text: His pay and emoluments were as before and he retained the same grading, namely Rs. 500-40-700. His earned increments were number affected and, except for the change in name, his companyditions of service were number worse than when he was in the service of the Bikaner State.

facts.text: Writ petition filed on April 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by this, the appellant filed the writ petition out of which this appeal arises on April 3, 1954.

facts.text: High Court held April 23, 1951 appointment as ad hoc, directed machinery for recruitment to Judicial Service.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the posting of April 23, 1951, which purports to appoint the appellant substantively as a Civil Judge, is wrong and that it must be treated as an ad hoc appointment till proper appointments are made to the Judicial Service of Rajasthan according to the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted on April 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment was delivered on September 5, 1955, and the appellant thereupon came here and was granted special leave to appeal on April 16, 1956.

facts.text: After High Court order, Rajasthan Government complied, reframed rules, made fresh appointments, appellant appointed Civil Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, according to the facts set out in the respondents statement of the case, the Rajasthan Government companyplied with the orders of the High Court, reframed their rules and made fresh appointments in accordance with them.

facts.text: Appellant contends April 23, 1951 order reduced him in rank without Art. 311 opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants companytention is that the order of April 23, 1951, reduced him in rank and as he was number afforded an opportunity of showing cause, Art. 311 of the Constitution was violated.

facts.text: Court finds old service contracts terminate upon integration, new terms by new state.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, companyquest, merger or integration, all companytracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and companyditions as the new State may choose to impose.

facts.text: Conditions of service not less advantageous than on November 1, 1948, fulfilled for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this companydition is fulfilled. But that apart, Article XVI 1  indicates that the old companytracts terminate just as they did in The State Of Madras K. M. Rajagopalan  1 .

facts.text: No reduction in rank, Art. 311 not attracted, previous postings transitional.

anchor.surface_text: But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, numberquestion of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is number attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary
under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The appellant was a District and Sessions Judge in the former Bikaner State.

arguments.claim: The order dated December 9, 1949 transferring the appellant as District and Sessions Judge to Ganganagar constitutes an election by the new Rajasthan Government to continue him in his original post as District and Sessions Judge permanently, and it could not later change its mind to make his service provisional.

anchor.surface_text: Among other contentions, the appellant relies on this as an election by the new Government to continue him in his original post and contends that it could not later change its mind and make his service provisional as it purported to do in the notification just cited.

arguments.claim: All contracts of service with prior government automatically terminate upon integration/merger; new service on terms imposed by new state.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate

arguments.claim: Article XVI(1) of Covenant guarantees only that conditions of service not less advantageous than on November 1, 1948; this was fulfilled for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled. But that apart, Article XVI 1 indicates that the old contracts terminate just as they did in The State Of Madras K. M. Rajagopalan 1 .

arguments.claim: Article XVI(1) indicates termination of old contracts as it provides options: continuance, compensation, or pension; continuance on fresh terms.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, there were three options 1 continuance in service, 2 payment of reasonable compensation, and 3 retirement on proportionate pension. That shows that the old contracts terminated

arguments.claim: December 9, 1949 order is mere transfer, part of transitional arrangements; not substantive appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The order of December 9,1949, on which the appellant relies, transferring him as District and Sessions Judge to the District Court at Ganganagar, must be read subject to the above and, if Article XVI 1 of the Covenant applies, then subject to that as well.

arguments.claim: Increment sanction orders are merely descriptive of prior status; do not fix permanent post.

arguments.claim: No reduction in rank occurred; all prior postings in new State were transitional and temporary; Article 311 not attracted.

arguments.claim: Conditions of service not less advantageous than in Bikaner State; pay, grading, increments same.

anchor.surface_text: His pay and emoluments were as before and he retained the same grading, namely Rs. 500-40-700. His earned increments were not affected and, except for the change in name, his conditions of service were not worse than when he was in the service of the Bikaner State.

holdings.text: when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State, and are taken on by it, serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on settled law from precedents including State of Madras v. K.M. Rajagopalan, Privy Council and House of Lords decisions; equates to master-servant principle on change of masters.

holdings.text: Article XVI 1 indicates that the old contracts terminate just as they did in The State Of Madras K. M. Rajagopalan. In the first place, there were three options 1 continuance in service, 2 payment of reasonable compensation, and 3 retirement on proportionate pension. That shows that the old contracts terminated and that those who continued in service did so on the basis of fresh contracts, the conditions of which had yet to be determined.

anchor.surface_text: Article XVI 1 indicates that the old contracts terminate just as they did in The State Of Madras K. M. Rajagopalan 1 . In the first place, there were three options 1 continuance in service, 2 payment of reasonable compensation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of options in Article XVI implying termination of old contracts and formation of fresh ones; no guarantee of same post, only not less advantageous conditions.

holdings.text: the conditions of their service will not be less advantageous than those on which they were serving on November 1, 1948. We have shown above that this condition is fulfilled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's pay, grading, increments remained the same; conditions not worse than in Bikaner State.

holdings.text: An order of transfer cannot be equated to an order of appointment and in any case, the new cadres had not been established and the new Courts under the proposed scheme of re-organisation had not been constituted, so, anything done at that stage could only have been part and parcel of the temporary transitional arrangements pending the final settlement by the new State of the schemes and conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: The order of December 9,1949, on which the appellant relies, transferring him as District and Sessions Judge to the District Court at Ganganagar, must be read subject to the above and, if Article XVI 1 of the Covenant applies,

holdings.reasoning_summary: December 9, 1949 order subject to Gazette of June 4, 1949 and Covenant; part of ad hoc transitional measures before final cadres.

holdings.text: The orders of March 25, 1950, and July 31, 1950, sanctioning the increment do not help the appellant... No determination to post the appellant permanently in a particular cadre and post can be spelled out of these accidental descriptions in orders dealing with a different matter.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of March 25, 1950, and July 31, 1950, sanctioning the increment do not help the appellant. He is described there as Shri Rajvi Amarsingh, District and Sessions Judge in Bikaner Division.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Descriptions incidental and descriptive; endorsement shows current ad hoc posting; not fixation of permanent cadre.

holdings.text: whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary

anchor.surface_text: But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted. All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior postings ad hoc and temporary post-integration; fresh appointment not reduction; Art 311 inapplicable to transitional arrangements.

holdings.text: so far as Art. XVI 1 of the Covenant is concerned, its guarantee has been fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: All his previous postings in the new State were purely transitional and temporary and so far as Art. XVI 1 of the Covenant is concerned, its guarantee has been fulfilled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates fulfillment of not less advantageous conditions based on pay and service continuity.

justification_sets.label: Article XVI of Rajasthan Integration Covenant support
Article XVI of Rajasthan Integration Covenant support

anchor.surface_text: The substantive appointment gazetted on April 23, 1951, after the new cadres and Courts had been fixed, was struck down by the High Court, and the Government of Rajasthan was directed to treat that as an ad hoc appointment. According to the respondent in its statement of the case, the matter was regularised after the High Courts decision and the appellant was again appointed a Civil Judge. If that is so, then this must be regarded as his first substantive appointment in the new State. But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, numberquestion of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is number attracted.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contention of reduction in rank violating Article 311 rejected; no reduction in rank as previous postings were transitional and temporary; guarantee under Article XVI of the Covenant fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well established that when one State is absorbed in another, whether by accession, conquest, merger or integration, all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and

The substantive appointment gazetted on April 23, 1951, after the new cadres and Courts had been fixed, was struck down by the High Court, and the Government of Rajasthan was directed to treat that as an ad hoc appointment. According to the respondent in its statement of the case, the matter was regularised after the High Courts decision and the appellant was again appointed a Civil Judge. If that is so, then this must be regarded as his first substantive appointment in the new State. But whether this is his first substantive appointment after the integration, or the one of April 23, 1951, numberquestion of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is number attracted.
